questions.question:
Consider the following relational schema:

\( \text{Students} (\text{\underline{rollno: integer,} name: string, age: integer, cgpa: real}) \)
\( \text{Courses} (\text{\underline{courseno: integer,} cname: string, credits: integer}) \)
\( \text{Enrolled} (\text{ \underline{rollno: integer,} \underline{courseno: integer,} grade: string}) \)

Which of the following options is/are correct SQL query/queries to retrieve the names of the students enrolled in course number (i.e. courseno) 1470?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)
options:
A.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE EXISTS (SELECT * FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)

B.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE SIZEOF (SELECT * FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno) > 0

C.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE 0 < (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)

D.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S NATURAL JOIN Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470
correct_answer:
A.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE EXISTS (SELECT * FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)

C.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE 0 < (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)

D.

SELECT S.name FROM Students S NATURAL JOIN Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the database transactions \(T1 \) and \(T2 \), and data items \(X \) and \(Y \). Which of the schedule(s) is/are conflict serializable?

\( \begin{array}{|l|} \hline \textbf{Transaction T1} \\ \hline R1(X) \\ \hline W1(Y) \\ \hline R1(X) \\ \hline W1(X) \\ \hline \text{COMMIT(T1)} \\ \hline \end{array} \)

\( \begin{array}{|l|} \hline \textbf{Transaction T2} \\ \hline W2(X) \\ \hline W2(Y) \\ \hline \text{COMMIT(T2)} \\ \hline \end{array} \)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)

questions.question:
An audit of a banking transactions system has found that on an earlier occasion, two joint holders of account \(A \) attempted simultaneous transfers of Rs. 10000 each from account \(A \) to account \(B \). Both transactions read the same value, Rs. 11000, as the initial balance in \(A \) and were allowed to go through. \(B \) was credited Rs. 10000 twice. \(A \) was debited only once and ended up with a balance of Rs. 1000.
Which of the following properties is/are certain to have been violated by the system?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-2)

questions.question:
Consider the following database tables of a sports league.

player(pid,pname,age)
coach(cid,cname)
team(tid,tname,city,cid)
members(pid,tid)

An instance of the table and an SQL query are given.

The value returned by the given SQL query is _________. (Answer in integer)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)

questions.question:
Consider a relational schema \( team(name, city, owner) \), with functional dependencies \(\{ name \to city \), \( name \to owner \} \) .

The relation \( team \) is decomposed into two relations, \( t_1(name, city) \) and \( t_2(name, owner) \). Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
A.

The relation \( team \) is NOT in BCNF.

B.

The relations \( t_1 \) and \( t_2 \) are in BCNF.
correct_answer:
B.

The relations \( t_1 \) and \( t_2 \) are in BCNF.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider two relations describing teams and players in a sports league:

\(teams(tid, tname):tid, tname \) are team-id and team-name, respectively
\(players(pid, pname, tid):pid,pname,tid\) denote player-id, player-name and the team-id of the player, respectively

Which ONE of the following tuple relational calculus queries returns the name of the players who play for the team having name as 'MI'?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
A.

\( \{ p.pname \mid p \in players \wedge \exists t ( t \in teams \wedge p.tid = t.tid \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} \)

B.

\( \{ p.pname \mid p \in teams \wedge \exists t ( t \in players \wedge p.tid = t.tid \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} \)

C.

\( \{ p.pname \mid p \in players \wedge \exists t ( t \in teams \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} \)

D.

\( \{ p.pname \mid p \in teams \wedge \exists t ( t \in players \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} \)
questions.correct_answer:
A.

\( \{ p.pname \mid p \in players \wedge \exists t ( t \in teams \wedge p.tid = t.tid \wedge t.tname = 'MI' ) \} \)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:

\( R_1(X) \quad W_1(Y) \quad R_2(X) \quad R_2(Y) \quad R_3(Y) \quad ABORT(T_1)\)

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)

questions.question:
A functional dependency \(F:X \rightarrow Y\) is termed as a useful functional dependency if and only if it satisfies all the following three conditions:

\(X\) is not the empty set. \(Y\) is not the empty set. Intersection of \(X\) and \(Y\) is the empty set.

For a relation \(R\) with 4 attributes, the total number of possible useful functional dependencies is ______

(GATE CSE 2024 SET-2)

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the Two Phase Locking (2PL) protocol is/are TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2024 SET-2)
options:
B.

With 2PL, a transaction always locks the data item being read or written just before every operation and always releases the lock just after the operation

C.

With 2PL, once a lock is released on any data item inside a transaction, no more locks on any data item can be obtained inside that transaction

questions.question:
In the context of owner and weak entity sets in the ER (Entity-Relationship) data model, which one of the following statements is TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2024 SET-2)
options:
A.

The weak entity set MUST have total participation in the identifying relationship

B.

The owner entity set MUST have total participation in the identifying relationship

C.

Both weak and owner entity sets MUST have total participation in the identifying relationship

D.

Neither weak entity set nor owner entity set MUST have total participation in the identifying relationship
questions.correct_answer:
A.

The weak entity set MUST have total participation in the identifying relationship
